questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize basophilic stippling as a key feature of lead poisoning , resulting from the disruption of heme synthesis and the accumulation of ribosomal material in red blood cells. This is important in diagnosing children exposed to lead, which can lead to significant anemia and other systemic effects
  • ➤ basophilic stippling
  • ➤ lead poisoning
  • ➤ ribosomal material

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ BAL (British anti-lewisite, dimercaprol) :
  • ➤ BAL (British anti-lewisite, dimercaprol)
  • ➤ It is used in arsenic, lead, bismuth, copper, mercury, gold and other heavy metal poisoning. Many heavy metals have affinity for sulfhydryl (–SH) radicals, combine with them in tissues and deprive the body of the use of respiratory enzymes. BAL has two unsaturated –SH groups which combine with the metal and thus prevent the union of the metal with the –SH group of the respiratory enzyme system. Dose: 10% solution in oil, 3–5 mg/kg IM 4 hourly for 2 days, 6 hourly on 3rd day and then 12 hourly for next 10 days . Side effects: Nausea , vomiting , headache and hypertension . Contraindicated in liver damage , G-6-PD deficient individuals, and cadmium and iron poisoning (since dimercaprol-cadmium and dimercaprol-iron complex is itself toxic).

questions.text: A hiker in a forested area is bitten by a snake while exploring. Hiker begins to experience symptoms such as swelling, pain, and bruising at the bite site. The hiker remains conscious but is anxious. What is the most appropriate initial first aid response for this snake bite?

options.text: Applying a tourniquet above the bite site to restrict blood flow and prevent venom spread.

options.label: B
options.text: Cutting open the wound and attempting to suck out the venom.

options.label: C
options.text: Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.

options.label: D
options.text: Applying ice packs directly to the bite area to reduce swelling and pain.

questions.correct_answer: C. Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Applying a tourniquet above the bite site to restrict blood flow and prevent venom spread . It can lead to gangrene.

  • • A
  • • Applying a tourniquet above the bite site
  • • blood flow and prevent venom spread
  • • Option B . Cutting open the wound and attempting to suck out the venom . It can introduce infections , increase absorption of the venom and increase local bleeding.
  • • Option
  • • B

  • • introduce infections
  • • Option D . Applying ice packs directly to the bite area to reduce swelling and pain . While ice packs are recommended in scorpion bite, it is not to be given in snake bite . Snake venom can contain enzymes that cause tissue damage and affect blood circulation. Cold temperature can constrict blood vessels and worsen the local damage.
  • • Option
  • • D

  • • scorpion bite, it is not to be given in snake bite

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents to the emergency department with severe pain, restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, and sweating after being stung by a scorpion. The sting site is red and swollen, with no signs of necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site

options.label: D
options.text: Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer prazosin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Administer antivenom immediately : Antivenom is given only in cases of severe envenomation with significant systemic symptoms, such as respiratory distress, cardiovascular instability etc.
  • • Option
  • • A
  • • Administer antivenom immediately
  • • Antivenom is given
  • • cases of severe envenomation
  • • Option B . Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site : Applying a tourniquet can worsen tissue damage , delay proper wound care, and increase the risk of complications.
  • • Option
  • • B
  • • Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site
  • • tourniquet can worsen tissue damage
  • • Option D . Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs : For cases with mild local symptoms , wound cleansing to prevent infection and the application of ice packs or cold compresses to the sting site can help alleviate pain and reduce swelling. However, in cases of significant systemic symptoms like restlessness, hypertension, and tachycardia, addressing the autonomic effects with prazosin is more crucial. The wound care is secondary, and ice pack can be applied later on.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs
  • • mild local symptoms
  • • wound cleansing to prevent infection

  • • not to be given in snake bite

Scorpion Antivenom: Anti-venom has to be given within 30 minutes of sting to be effective. So useful only in limited cases which present very early. Also, it is reserved for cases of severe envenomation only.

  • • neurological symptoms
  • • peripheral neuropathy

  • • Option
  • • C
  • • Thallium
  • • poisoning
  • • severe
  • • alopecia
  • • hair
  • • loss
  • • painful
  • • neuropathies
  • • Option D . Mercury exposure can lead to neurological symptoms and acrodynia (pink disease), but it is not associated with the specific dermatological findings seen in arsenic poisoning.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Mercury
  • • neurological symptoms and acrodynia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The dermatological manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning - Rash resembling fading measles rash , Speckled brown pigmentation , mostly on the skin flexures, temples, shoulders, eyelids and neck (raindrop pigmentation). Macular areas of depigmentation may appear on normal/hyperpigmented skin (leucomelanosis). Hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles with irregular thickening of the nails and development of white bands of opacity in the nails of fingers and toes (called Aldrich-Mees lines). Brittle nails and alopecia are also seen.

questions.text: Treatment of methyl alcohol poisoning includes all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Forced Alkaline Diuresis

  • ➤ Forced alkaline diuresis is ineffective in treating methyl alcohol poisoning because it cannot eliminate strong acids like formic acid. The primary treatments include ethanol or fomepizole, hemodialysis, and sodium bicarbonate for acidosis management.

  • • euphoria
  • • altered perception
  • • Option D . Heroin : Heroin is an opioid and typically causes sedation , respiratory depression, and constricted pupils (miosis). It does not typically produce the sympathetic overactivity seen with cocaine use.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department in labor pains. The couple was previously counseled about their unique pregnancy after routine ultrasound findings. Upon examination, the casualty medical officer notes that the patient is indeed in labor and proceeds with the delivery. Surprisingly, she gives birth to twins at term. The first neonate appears slightly smaller and less developed compared to the second. Subsequent investigations reveal that the first neonate's gestational age is approximately 32 weeks, while the second neonate's gestational age is around 36 weeks. The medical officer is puzzled by this finding, considering the implications of such a rare event in their medical practice. How can the difference in gestational ages between the twins be best explained?

  • • Option B. Superfecundation : Fertilization of two ova discharged from the ovary at the same period of ovulation by two different acts of coitus committed at short intervals . The term is also used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings, classic example being one baby is white and the other black.

Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time. Whereas, in superfetation, either they are born at same time but with different development or born at different times with same development.

  • • Some important pointers related to IMMUNOLOGICAL TESTS –
  • • The hormone chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) and human chorionic somatomamnotropin (HCS) are secreted by the syncytial trophoblastic cells into the fluids of the mother. It can be detected in maternal blood on about the 8th day after impregnation. The rate of secretion rises rapidly to reach a maximum about seven weeks after conception, and decreases to a relatively low volume by 16 weeks after conception. Because they are convenient and very reliable (accuracy 98% ), they have replaced bioassays for routine screening. An early morning urine specimen will contain the highest level of HCG and is preferable for testing. Tests are positive 12 to 15 days after implantation.

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a workshop on various tests used to determine live birth in cases of infant death. These tests are essential to distinguish between infants who were born alive and those who were stillborn. Which of the following tests is not used to detect live birth?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Winslow test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Fodere's test is used to demonstrate lung floatation , indicative of breathing and thus live birth . The lungs are ligated across their hila and separated . The average weight of both lungs before respiration varies from 30 to 40 g., and after respiration from 60 to 66 g. The increase in weight is due to the increased flow of blood.
  • • Option A
  • • Fodere's test
  • • demonstrate lung floatation
  • • breathing and thus live birth
  • • ligated across their hila and separated
  • • Option B . Ploucquet's test is another lung floatation test used to determine if an infant had breathed . The ratio of the weight of the lungs and the whole body is reduced to half (1/35 of body weight) as compared to the said ratio before respiration (1/70 of body weight).
  • • Option B
  • • Ploucquet's test
  • • lung floatation test
  • • if an infant had breathed
  • • Option C . Wredin's test - Before birth , the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue but no air . With respiration, the sphincter at the pharyngeal end of eustachian tube relaxes and air replaces the gelatinous substances in few hours to five weeks.
  • • Option C
  • • Wredin's test
  • • Before birth
  • • middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue but no air

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding different forensic tests used to detect live birth and distinguishing them from tests that serve other purposes.
  • ➤ forensic tests used to detect live birth
  • ➤ Winslow test = test to determine stoppage of respiration Fodere's test = weight of lungs before respiration -30 to 40 g after respiration-60 to 66 g Plocquet's test = ratio of weight of lungs to weight of body ; before respiration = 1:70 and after respiration = 1:35 Wredin's test = before respiration gelatinous tissue in middle ear & after respiration , air in middle ear
  • ➤ Winslow test = test to determine stoppage of respiration

  • ➤ Fodere's test = weight of lungs before respiration -30 to 40 g after respiration-60 to 66 g

  • ➤ weight of lungs before respiration -30 to 40 g after respiration-60 to 66 g
  • ➤ Plocquet's test = ratio of weight of lungs to weight of body ; before respiration = 1:70 and after respiration = 1:35
  • ➤ Plocquet's test
  • ➤ weight of lungs to weight of body
  • ➤ Wredin's test = before respiration gelatinous tissue in middle ear & after respiration , air in middle ear
  • ➤ Wredin's test

questions.text: In a lecture on child abuse, the professor discusses Caffey's Syndrome, a condition often associated with non-accidental injuries in children. The students are asked to identify which feature is not true regarding Caffey's Syndrome. Which of the following statements about Caffey's Syndrome is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Undue delay in seeking medical advice

options.label: C
options.text: The history is consistent with the injuries

questions.correct_answer: C. The history is consistent with the injuries
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The history is consistent with the injuries.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Injuries sustained are non-accidental : True , as Caffey's Syndrome is often linked to child abuse.
  • • Option A
  • • Injuries sustained are non-accidental
  • • True
  • • Option B . Undue delay in seeking medical advice: True , and this delay in seeking treatment is a common feature in child abuse cases.
  • • Option B
  • • Undue delay in seeking medical advice: True
  • • Option D . Injuries are of different duration: True , indicating repeated abuse over time, with injuries in various stages of healing.
  • • Option D
  • • Injuries are of different duration: True

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of nonaccidental violence , produced by a parent or guardian . In addition to physical injury , there may be non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care and affection . The key identifier is the inconsistency between the history provided and the injuries observed, which is a hallmark of non-accidental injury in child abuse cases.
  • ➤ battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of nonaccidental violence
  • ➤ parent or guardian
  • ➤ physical injury
  • ➤ non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care and affection
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 445
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 445

questions.text: During a medical conference, a discussion arises about the different causes of spontaneous abortion in the second trimester. What is the most common cause of spontaneous abortion in the second trimester?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cervical incompetence

  • • Less common

  • • Option D . Infections : While a potential cause , they are not as common as cervical incompetence in the second trimester.

  • • Infections

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a postmortem examination in a district hospital on a 45-year-old male who was found dead in his home office. The deceased had a history of depression but no known physical health issues. The postmortem reveals no signs of physical trauma, but a white crystalline substance is found in the stomach contents. Toxicological analysis identifies the substance as borax. In this suspected suicide case, which pharmacological effect of borax is most pertinent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Emmenagogues

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Gastrointestinal irritants : These causes irritation of uterus , e.g. purgatives, like castor or croton oil, julap, senna or MgSO4.
  • • Option A
  • • Gastrointestinal irritants
  • • irritation of uterus
  • • Option B . Genitourinary irritants : They produce reflex uterine contraction , e.g. cantharides, oil of turpentine or tansy or pennyroyal.
  • • Option B
  • • Genitourinary irritants
  • • reflex uterine contraction
  • • Option C . Ecbolics : Refers to substances that stimulate uterine contractions . Ex - Ergot preparations, synthetic estrogens, pituitary extract, strychnine or quinine.
  • • Option C
  • • Ecbolics
  • • substances that stimulate uterine contractions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abortifacient drugs: Most of them have no effect on the uterus or fetus , unless given in toxic doses , and often sold to exploit distressed woman . Usually used in the 2nd month of pregnancy .

questions.text: In a pathology laboratory, a medical officer is analyzing tissue samples from a deceased pregnant woman who suddenly collapsed and died. The medical history and symptoms prior to death suggest a rare but serious complication. The medical officer decides to use Lendrum's stain in the histopathological examination of the lung tissue. For which type of embolism is Lendrum's stain specifically used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amniotic fluid embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Air embolism : Not identifiable with Lendrum's stain .
  • • Option A
  • • Air embolism
  • • Not identifiable with Lendrum's stain
  • • Option B . Fat embolism : Detected through different staining techniques .
  • • Option B
  • • Fat embolism
  • • different staining techniques
  • • Option D. Pulmonary embolism : The nature of the embolus (e.g., thrombus, fat, air) dictates the staining technique, not the location.
  • • Option D.
  • • Pulmonary embolism
  • • nature of the embolus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lendrum's stain is used in forensic pathology for the identification of amniotic fluid embolism , a critical diagnostic tool in cases of maternal death where this condition is suspected.

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a forensic examination in a case involving a late-term abortion. To assist in determining the gestational age of the fetus at the time of the abortion, the medical officer is reviewing the mother's medical records for documented physical examination findings. External ballottement is a technique used to assess fetal development. After how many weeks of gestation can external ballottement typically be performed in a normal pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 20 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • External ballottement , a technique where the fetus can be felt to rebound against the examiner's fingers during a pelvic examination, is typically possible after about 20 weeks of gestation . This is when the fetus is large enough to be palpated through the abdominal wall.
  • • External ballottement
  • • fetus can be felt to rebound against the examiner's fingers during a pelvic examination,
  • • possible after about 20 weeks of gestation
  • • fetus is large enough to be palpated
  • • Demonstration
  • • Demonstration
  • • Vaginal/internal ballottement : Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix and a sudden upward motion given . This causes the fetus to move up in the liquor amnii and after a moment, the fetus drops down on the fingers, like a ball bouncing back. External ballottement : A sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus, in a few seconds the rebound of the fetus can be felt.
  • • Vaginal/internal ballottement : Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix and a sudden upward motion given . This causes the fetus to move up in the liquor amnii and after a moment, the fetus drops down on the fingers, like a ball bouncing back.
  • • Vaginal/internal ballottement
  • • Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix
  • • upward motion given
  • • fetus to move up in the liquor amnii
  • • External ballottement : A sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus, in a few seconds the rebound of the fetus can be felt.
  • • External ballottement
  • • sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ballottement (toss up like a ball): This is positive during the 4th–5th month of pregnancy as the fetus is small in relation to the amount of amniotic fluid present . This is a useful clinical sign for assessing fetal development around the midpoint of the gestation period.
  • ➤ Ballottement (toss up like a ball):
  • ➤ positive during the 4th–5th month of pregnancy
  • ➤ fetus is small in relation to the amount of amniotic fluid present

questions.text: In a case under investigation at a district hospital, a medical officer is required to estimate the gestational age of a fetus as part of a forensic examination. This is crucial in a legal case involving questions around the time of conception and fetal viability. The medical officer refers to ultrasound findings for accurate dating of the pregnancy. At the earliest, by which week of gestation can the gestational sac be seen using ultrasonography?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 5th week

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . 3rd week - Not visible
  • • Option A

  • • Option B
  • • 4th week
  • • after 4 completed week
  • • Option D . 8th week : By this time, more advanced fetal structures, beyond just the gestational sac, are visible in forensic ultrasonography , like - Eyes and nose recognizable, hands and feet are webbed. Anus is seen as dark spot. Placenta is formed.
  • • Option D
  • • 8th week
  • • advanced fetal structures, beyond just the gestational sac, are visible in forensic ultrasonography

questions.text: During a postmortem examination of a pregnant woman at a district hospital, a medical officer is investigating a case involving suspected complications related to fetomaternal hemorrhage. To determine if there was a transfusion of fetal red blood cells (RBCs) into the mother's circulation, a specific diagnostic test is required. Which test is used to detect fetomaternal transfusion of fetal RBCs in the mother's circulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Betke-Kleihauer test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Direct Coomb’s test : Detects antibodies on the surface of red blood cells , not specifically for fetomaternal transfusion.
  • • Option A.
  • • Direct Coomb’s test
  • • antibodies on the surface of red blood cells
  • • fetomaternal transfusion.
  • • Option C . Electrophoresis : Used for analyzing the mobility of charged particles , not specific to this scenario.
  • • Option C
  • • Electrophoresis
  • • analyzing the mobility of charged particles
  • • Option D . Indirect Coomb’s test : Detects antibodies in the mother's serum , often used in blood typing and antibody screening , but not specific to fetomaternal transfusion.
  • • Option D
  • • Indirect Coomb’s test
  • • antibodies in the mother's serum
  • • blood typing and antibody screening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Betke-Kleihauer test during postmortem examinations of pregnant women , helps in detecting fetomaternal transfusion of fetal red blood cells in the mother's circulation. This knowledge is crucial in forensic postmortem examinations of pregnant women , particularly in cases where fetomaternal hemorrhage is suspected, to establish the cause and circumstances of complications or death.

  • ➤ fetomaternal transfusion of fetal red blood cells in the mother's circulation.

questions.text: In a rural district hospital, a medical officer was called to investigate a distressing case involving a newborn found abandoned near a local pond. The circumstances surrounding the newborn's discovery raised concerns about possible infanticide. To assist in the investigation, the medical officer decided to perform a series of tests as part of the autopsy to determine whether the newborn had been born alive and breathed before death. In which test weight of lungs is compared with body weight?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ploucquet's Test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Static test or Fodere's test: The test based on lung weight useful in the diagnosis of live birth is static test . The average weight of both lungs before respiration is 35 gm and after respiration is 70 gm. There is no comparison with the body weight.
  • • Option A. Static test or Fodere's test:
  • • test based on lung weight useful in the diagnosis of live birth is static test
  • • Option C. Raygat’s test (Hydrostatic test, Breslau’s 1st life test): Raygat’s test is based on specific gravity of lung . The specific gravity of a non-respired lung is 1040-1050 and of a respired lung is 940-950, so, after respiration lung floats on water (specific gravity of water is 1000). There is no comparison of lung weight to body weight.
  • • Option C. Raygat’s test (Hydrostatic test, Breslau’s 1st life test):
  • • Raygat’s test is based on specific gravity of lung
  • • Option D. Wredin's test: This test is based on the fact that before birth middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic tissue , which is replaced by air after respiration. So, the presence of air in middle ears denotes live birth. There is no role of weight of lungs.
  • • Option D. Wredin's test: This test is based on the fact that before birth middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic tissue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 439
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 439
